query: What kind of assistance can you provide based on the code of conduct?
reference:
Based on the Code of Conduct, I can provide assistance with:
- Understanding the principles and expectations outlined in the Code for employees and managers
- Guidance on reporting concerns and cooperating with investigations
- Information on the responsibilities of managers to set an ethical example
- Details on the firm's zero tolerance for unethical behavior and consequences for violations
- Access to the full Code of Conduct document for reference

context:
Code of Conduct
About this Document
The Code of Conduct ("Code") sets forth the expectation that employees conduct 
themselves with integrity, at all times. It provides employees with the principles to 
help govern their conduct with clients, customers, suppliers, vendors, shareholders, 
fellow employees, regulators, markets, and the communities in which we operate. 
The Code applies to the employees and directors of JPMorgan Chase & Co. ("firm" or 
"JPMorganChase") and its direct and indirect subsidiaries. 
The Code is designed to be consistent with the regulatory and legal 
framework that governs our industry. It may be amended as required by law, 
regulation or otherwise. All amendments are effective immediately upon posting. 
The Code is administered by Code of Conduct Compliance. The most current 
version can be accessed on our firm’s internal and external websites. 
Code of Conduct Compliance can provide interpretative guidance on the principles 
in the Code, in consultation with LOB Compliance, the Chief Compliance Officer or 
the General Counsel, as appropriate. Any waiver of the provisions of this Code or

Code. Compliance with the Code is a condition of employment. Action may 
be taken against employees who violate the Code or who fail to report the 
violations of others, up to and including termination of employment. 
Managers have an even greater level of responsibility. They must set the

Code of Conduct

strive to abide by the letter and spirit of the laws and regulations everywhere we do 
business and have zero tolerance for unethical behavior. Personal accountability and

we do matters and has significant impact in the communities where we operate. 
Therefore, we must always act with integrity and be responsible for our actions. 
Respect for each other as well as those with whom we do business is not only 
expected but required.

query: Which department is responsible for addressing employee concerns at JP Morgan Chase?
reference: Human Resources is the department responsible for addressing employee concerns at JP Morgan Chase.
generated_text: Human Resources is the department responsible for addressing employee concerns at JP Morgan Chase.
context:
Code of Conduct
Report a Potential Violation or Concern
Every JPMorganChase employee has both the right and the 
obligation to report actual and potential violations of our Code 
and firm policies, as well as laws and regulations that govern 
JPMorganChase business. 
There are several ways to report a potential or actual violation 
or raise a concern. Reporting can be done anonymously,

1.4 Sharing Concerns
1.3.1 Manager Responsibilities
Use your voice and escalate your concerns, regardless of whether it directly 
affects you or your department. Promptly report any potential or actual 
violations of the Code, firm policy, or law or regulation related to our 
business. You are encouraged to ask questions and have open conversations 
with your manager on business and conduct issues. We rely on you to speak 
up when something is unclear. 
If you witness or suspect that something is illegal or unethical, you have the 
right and an obligation to share your concerns. You must immediately report 
to Human Resources certain charges or arrests that involve you personally, 
whether they relate to the business of our firm or not. 
There are several ways to report your concerns. You can raise issues with 
your manager, your Compliance Officer, Global Security or Human

query: What is the process for reporting a potential violation or concern at JP Morgan Chase?
reference:
To report a potential violation or concern at JP Morgan Chase, you have several options:

1. Contact the JPMorganChase Conduct Hotline:
   - For U.S. and Canada: 1-855-JPMCODE
   - All others: Use the online submission form (click here link provided)

2. Submit a report online through the designated portal (link provided)

3. Report via mobile device by scanning the provided QR code

Employees have both the right and obligation to report actual or potential violations of the Code of Conduct, firm policies, laws, and regulations. Reporting can be done anonymously where permitted by law. JPMorganChase strictly prohibits retaliation against anyone who reports in good faith. For concerns related to accounting, internal controls, auditing, or financial reporting, you can also contact the Office of the General Counsel at 383 Madison Avenue, New York, NY 10179.

query: What are the responsibilities and duties of a manager at JP Morgan Chase according to the code of conduct?
reference:
According to JP Morgan Chase's Code of Conduct, managers have several key responsibilities and duties related to upholding the firm's ethical culture and standards:

1. Set the example and tone for ethical conduct. Managers must lead with integrity in their words and actions.

2. Reinforce the firm's ethical culture. Managers are responsible for promoting and maintaining the Code of Conduct among their teams.

3. Serve as the first resource for employees with questions on ethical issues or firm policies. If unsure, managers must direct employees to the correct resources.

4. Report any misconduct they know about and escalate appropriately. Managers have a greater level of responsibility to identify and address violations of the Code.

5. Create an environment where others feel comfortable sharing concerns. Managers must foster a culture of openness and ensure employees can raise issues without fear of retaliation.

Failure to uphold these responsibilities can result in disciplinary action up to and including termination of employment. Managers play a critical role in maintaining the firm's high standards of integrity and compliance.

2. Reinforce the firm's ethical culture. Managers are responsible for promoting and maintaining the Code of Conduct among their teams.

3. Serve as the first resource for employees with questions on ethical issues or firm policies. If unsure, managers must direct employees to the correct resources.

4. Report any misconduct they know about and escalate appropriately. Managers have a greater level of responsibility to identify and address violations of the Code.

5. Create an environment where others feel comfortable sharing concerns. Managers must foster a culture of openness and ensure employees can raise issues without fear of retaliation.

Failure to uphold these responsibilities can result in disciplinary action up to and including termination of employment. Managers play a critical role in maintaining the firm's high standards of integrity and compliance.

standards. Always provide first-class service in a first-class way.

query: What are the ethics guidelines for employees at JP Morgan Chase?
reference:
The key ethics guidelines for JP Morgan Chase employees, as outlined in the company's Code of Conduct, include:

1. Maintaining personal integrity and never lowering standards
2. Dealing fairly and in good faith with customers, suppliers, competitors, business partners, regulators and other employees
3. Never taking unfair advantage through manipulation, concealment, abuse of privileged/confidential information, misrepresentation or other unfair practices
4. Complying with laws and regulations related to market integrity
5. Reporting any known or suspected violations

query: What should employees do if they witness illegal activity within the company?
reference: Employees who witness illegal activity within the company should promptly report the conduct concerns to the appropriate channels as outlined in the company's Code of Conduct. This includes using the firm's confidential reporting system, speaking with Human Resources, or contacting the JPMorganChase Conduct Hotline. Employees are required to report violations and must cooperate with any investigations. Retaliation against those who report concerns is strictly prohibited.

query: Does JP Morgan Chase have a non-retaliation policy, and if so, what does it entail?
reference: Yes, JP Morgan Chase has a non-retaliation policy as part of its Code of Conduct. The policy states that employees are protected from retaliation for reporting concerns of potential or actual violations to management, directors, government, regulators, attorneys, or courts. It also prohibits intimidation or retaliation against anyone who assists with an inquiry or investigation of violations. Employees who experience or are aware of possible retaliatory action should report it to their manager, Human Resources, or the JPMorganChase Conduct Hotline. The policy emphasizes that employees can report concerns without fear of retaliation.

query: Are employees allowed to exchange gifts with external individuals with whom they have a professional relationship, but who are not employed by JP Morgan Chase?
reference: According to JP Morgan Chase's Code of Conduct, employees are generally allowed to exchange gifts with external individuals they have a professional relationship with, as long as the gift exchange does not create a perceived or actual conflict of interest, violate laws or regulations, or breach firm policies. Employees should avoid accepting or providing gifts to customers, suppliers, and business partners if it could suggest impropriety or provide an unfair advantage. Soliciting, suggesting, or requesting gifts in exchange for firm business is also prohibited. The key is to ensure gift exchanges are appropriate and do not compromise the firm's integrity or create conflicts.

other people or organizations where you or your family have a significant 
personal connection or financial interest. 
8
About Report 1.0 2.0 3.0Contents 4.0
 
Closing

JPMorganChase policies and restrictions on disclosing confidential information 
do not prevent employees from reporting concerns of any potential or actual 
violation to our firm's management or directors, the government, a regulator, 
employees' attorneys, or a court under seal. They also do not prevent 
employees from reporting retaliation for reporting such concerns or 
responding truthfully to questions or requests from the government, a 
regulator, or in a court of law.

before sharing it with anyone. Confidential information should never be 
disclosed to anyone inside or outside our firm except as permitted by law, in the 
proper conduct of our business, where disclosure is required by legal process, 
or where the Compliance or the Legal Department otherwise determines it is 
appropriate. The loss or unauthorized disclosure of confidential information 
may harm our firm and its clients and may result in termination of employment. 
Working remotely is considered an extension of the workplace. Uphold the

11
About Report 1.0 2.0 3.0Contents 4.0
 
Closing
Your responsibility to protect confidential information also applies to work you 
may have done before coming to JPMorganChase. Sharing confidential 
information from a former employer is unethical and can expose you and 
JPMorganChase to legal liabilities.

query: What guidelines or policies govern how employees are expected to manage information within the organization?
reference:
The primary policy governing how employees are expected to manage information within the organization is the company's Code of Conduct, specifically Section 3.1 "Managing Information". Key guidelines include:

- Protect confidential or material non-public information from unauthorized use or disclosure.
- Access or use information only if you have a legitimate business need.
- Do not use personal devices or unapproved applications to manage firm information.
- Speak up about any conduct that might violate the Code or firm policies.
- Managers must set an example, lead with integrity, and create an environment where concerns can be shared.
- Reporting concerns or cooperating with investigations is required, even if it involves disclosing confidential information.
- Retaliation for reporting is prohibited.

Code of Conduct
3.1 Managing Information
As an employee of a publicly traded company, you may have access to 
confidential or material, non-public information about our firm, clients and other 
companies that conduct or seek to do business with us. You must protect this 
information from unauthorized use, including from other employees who do not 
have a legitimate and continuous business need to access the information. 
Customers, suppliers, employees, and others who do business with our firm 
trust us to be good stewards of their financial, personal, and business 
information. No matter the format, protect information you manage on behalf of 
the firm from theft, loss, or unauthorized access or disclosure. Do not discuss, 
access, or use confidential and/or proprietary information unless you have a 
legitimate business need to do so. Do not use personal devices or applications 
that are not approved by the firm (e.g., Otter, Rocketbook, Code Beautification, 
or personal email domains) to manage or send information related to the firm’s 
business.

query: Does JP Morgan Chase prioritize diversity and inclusion in its hiring practices?
reference: Agent stopped due to iteration limit or time limit.
generated_text: Agent stopped due to iteration limit or time limit.
context:
Code of Conduct
4.2 Diversity and Inclusion is a Priority4.1 A Dynamic and Thriving Workplace
We recognize that our people are our strength, and the diverse talents and 
perspectives our employees bring to our global workforce are directly 
linked to our success. We seek to attract and retain the best talent and are 
dedicated to providing equal employment opportunity across all 
backgrounds. We strive to build and foster an inclusive work environment 
where our employees are respected, trusted, and empowered. We believe 
that if our teams are more diverse, we will generate better ideas and 
outcomes, enjoy a stronger corporate culture, and strengthen our 
competitive advantage.
We prohibit discrimination, harassment, bias and prejudice in our 
workplace and against our workforce based on an individual’s race, color, 
national origin or ancestry, ethnic origin, citizenship status, creed, religion, 
religious affiliation, religious views, age, sex, gender, pregnancy, maternity, 
paternity, caring responsibilities, marital status, relationship status, civil 
partnership, sexual orientation, transgender status, gender identity,

gender expression, intersex status, genetic information, physical or mental 
disability or protected condition, military or veteran status, an individual 
having been a victim of domestic violence, sexual assault or abuse, an 
individual being the victim of a crime, any other community group 
protected under applicable law, or any other status protected under 
applicable local law.
We do not tolerate discrimination, harassment, or inappropriate or abusive 
conduct by or against employees, customers, suppliers, contractors, or 
any other individuals who conduct business or seek to do business with 
our firm based on race, color, ethnicity, religion, religious affiliation, 
religious views, national origin or ancestry, gender, military status, 
disability, marital or familial status, political opinions, speech, or affiliations, 
age, or any status protected under applicable local law. 
We take all allegations of discrimination or harassment seriously. It is each 
employee's responsibility to report any concern or conduct that is or may 
be unlawful, abusive, or otherwise violates firm policies.

Code of Conduct
Closing Thoughts
Our core values are at the heart of what we do. Managers set the “tone from the 
top” and remind employees that it is paramount for each of us to be culture 
carriers. You must always maintain your personal integrity and never lower your 
standards. Always provide first-class service in a first-class way.
The people, products and services, and dedication to integrity have made 
JPMorganChase one of the largest and most successful financial institutions in 
the world. Just as we are a leader in the financial industry, we want to be known 
as a leader in business ethics.
Our collective commitment to being accountable, straightforward, and honest in 
all of our business dealings makes JPMorganChase a respected company. 
Encourage others to deal fairly with clients and suppliers, be good stewards of 
the firm’s resources, and foster an inclusive work environment.
Remember, it is your responsibility to report any violations you know about and 
those you suspect. JPMorganChase doesn’t tolerate retaliation against anyone 
who raises an issue or concern in good faith.
